Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Okay, lets tackle this problem step by step. First, I need to figure out which cases are taking longer. The process steps are pretty standard: submit, evaluate, request docs, approve, pay, close. The duration for each case would be the time from the first event (Submit Claim) to the last event (Close Claim). So I should calculate the duration for each case and then see which ones are in the upper percentiles, maybe the longest ones.

Name: Backtracking - NE
Text: Case 2002: ... From 09:05 to 24:00 on the first day is 14 hours 55 minutes. Then from 00:00 to 11:00 next day is 11 hours. Total is 14h55m + 11h = 25h55m? Wait, maybe better to calculate day by day. Wait, from April 1 9:05 to April 2 9:05 is exactly 24 hours. Then from 9:05 to 11:00 is another 1h55m. So total 25h55m?

Name: Backtracking - NE
Text: Case 2003: ... From April 1 9:10 to April 2 9:10 is 24 hours. Then from April 2 9:10 to April 3 9:30 is 23 hours 20 minutes. So total 24 + 23h20m = 47h20m? Wait, no. ... total 24h + 23h50m = 47h50m?

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: Case 2005: ... Let me convert each timestamp to minutes since a reference, then subtract start from end. ... April 4 14:30 is 3*24*60 + 14*60 +30 = 4320 + 870 = 5190 minutes. ... duration is 5190 -575 = 4615 minutes. 4615 minutes divided by 60 is 76.916666... hours

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Comparing all cases: Case 2001: ~1.5 hours Case 2002: ~25.9 hours ... Case 2005: ~76.9 hours ... So the cases with the longest durations are 2003 and 2005, then 2002. ... cases 2003, 2002, and 2005 are the ones with performance issues.
